intro: Crocus roopiae, commonly known as the Persian crocus, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a member of the Iridaceae family, characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10–20 centimeters, with narrow, grass-like leaves. Its flowers are usually pale yellow to orange in color, with a distinctive, waxy appearance. Crocus roopiae prefers well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy perennial in suitable climates.
